title: Agentic AI Course
text:
Design, diagram, implement, evaluate, productize, and scale agentic AI systems using modern LLM frameworks and tooling.
Identify and evaluate problems that are appropriate for agentic AI solutions, and distinguish them from problems better solved by traditional software or non-agentic LLM approaches.
Clearly define Agentic AI and related concepts, including agents, tools, planning, grounding, orchestration, evaluation, and human-in-the-loop workflows.
Develop and articulate ethical guidelines for the use of LLMs and agentic AI, including responsible data usage, AI governance principles, safety, privacy, and organizational policy considerations.
Build the capability to independently learn, evaluate, and adapt to new AI models, tools, and paradigms in a rapidly evolving AI ecosystem.

title: Agentic AI Dictionary
text:
Agentic AI Dictionary

Agent
A software system that can take in information, reason about what to do, and take actions, often repeatedly, to achieve a goal.


Agentic AI
An approach to AI where systems are built as agents that plan, use tools, remember information, and act autonomously or semi-autonomously rather than just generating single responses.


API (Application Programming Interface)
A set of rules that lets software systems talk to each other, such as an agent calling a weather service, database, or payment system.


Architecture (Agent Architecture)
The overall design of how an agent is structured, including how it reasons, stores memory, calls tools, and loops through tasks.


DAGs (Directed Acyclic Graphs)
A way to represent workflows as connected steps with a clear order and no loops. Often used to model structured agent workflows or pipelines.


Deliberative Agent
An agent that explicitly plans its actions before executing them, rather than reacting immediately.


Determinism
How consistent an agent’s outputs are when given the same input. Lower randomness (temperature) leads to more deterministic behavior.


ELT (Extract, Load, Transform)
A data workflow where data is collected, stored, and then transformed later. Common in systems where agents need access to raw data.


EtLT (Extract, Transform Lightly, Load, Transform)
A hybrid data approach where minimal cleanup happens before storage, followed by more detailed processing later.


Evaluation (Evals)
Methods used to measure how well an agent performs, including correctness, reliability, cost, latency, and safety.


Function Calling / Tool Calling
A structured way for an agent to choose and invoke tools (APIs, functions, databases) instead of responding only with text.


Grounding
Connecting an agent’s responses to real, trusted data sources (like databases or documents) to improve accuracy and reduce hallucinations.


Guardrails
Rules and constraints that prevent unsafe, unethical, or unwanted agent behavior.


Human-in-the-Loop (HITL)
Workflows where a human reviews, approves, or edits an agent’s actions or plans before they are executed.


Memory
Information an agent can store and reuse.
- Short-term memory: recent conversation or task context
- Long-term memory: stored facts, documents, or embeddings


Multi-Agent System
A system where multiple agents work together, often with different roles or responsibilities.


Observability
The ability to see what an agent is doing internally, including its prompts, tool calls, decisions, and errors.


Orchestration
The coordination of agent steps, tools, and workflows so tasks happen in the correct order and failures are handled.


Perception
How an agent receives and interprets inputs such as user messages, documents, API responses, or web data.


Planning
The process of breaking a goal into smaller steps before acting.


Prompt
Instructions or input given to a language model.
- System prompt: high-level rules and behavior
- User prompt: user input
- Tool prompt: information returned from tools


Prompt Injection
A security risk where malicious input attempts to override an agent’s instructions or policies.


RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation)
A technique where relevant documents or data are retrieved at runtime and provided to the model before it generates a response.


Reactive Agent
An agent that responds immediately to inputs without long-term planning or reasoning.


Reflection
An agent’s ability to review its own output or mistakes and adjust future behavior.


State
All information that defines where an agent is in a task, including memory, progress, and tool results.


Tool
An external capability an agent can use, such as an API, database, calculator, or web search.


Workflow
A structured sequence of steps that an agent follows to complete a task.

title: Module 1: Setup and Intro to LLM Programming
text:
Install Python, VS Code, Dependancies
Get Gemini API Key
Build small Agentic AI project




Welcome to the Agentic AI Course! In this course, you’ll learn how to build, evaluate, and scale agentic AI systems using Python and Google Gemini. You’ll explore key concepts like agents, tools, planning, and human-in-the-loop workflows, and learn to identify which problems are best solved with agentic AI. We’ll also cover ethical and responsible AI use, and give you the skills to stay up to date with new AI tools and approaches in a fast changing field.



The setup for the course is not very intensive and many of you likely have already completed much of the work already through other course. We wiil need the following:


If you already have python installed feel free to skip this step. If not, please visit the link below and download python onto your machine

Python




If you already have VS Code installed or you use another IDE with which you are comfortable then please feel free to skip this step. If not, please visit the link below and download VS Code onto your machine

VS Code

VS Code offers extensions by clicking the boxes icon on the left side of the screen
Here are some recommended VS Code extensions to get started:

Python – Makes Python easier by offering language support, debugging, and linting
Pylance – Makes Python even easier, works well with the above

Jupyter – Enables running and editing Jupyter notebooks directly in VS Code
GitLens – Enhances Git integration with code authorship, history, and insights
Prettier – Automatically formats code for consistent style
Bracket Pair Colorizer – Makes it easier to match brackets by color coding them
Live Share – Allows real time collaboration and pair programming




This class will be using this website, but we will be running the code on your own machines. We highly recommend setting up a folder system like this:
AgenticAI-Course/
│
├─ notebooks/          # Jupyter notebooks and example scripts
│
├─ src/                # Python scripts and modules you create
│
├─ data/               # Any datasets or downloaded resources
│
├─ models/             # Saved AI models, checkpoints, or outputs
│
├─  outputs/           # Results, logs, and exported files
│
└─ .env                # Environment variables, API keys, and secrets



An API key is a password for someone’s services. It opens the door of communication between your computer and their servers. In accessing Gemini with Python, you send your prompt and API key to their server; if the key is accepted, it will process your prompt and return its response (along with some other metadata). It is your first step to opening the AI door. Let’s get one!

Access the developer’s site for Gemini here: Gemini API key
You will need to sign in

If it doesn’t work, make sure you are using a personal Google account, not your school email
Secondly, if it says you don’t have access in your region, you may need to verify your age in your Google account settings

If this becomes too much of a hassle, you use an OpenAI API key instead, but you will have to pay $5 and become familiar with what code to change as you go through the course (slight added complexity, but really not that much)


A key should be created automatically. You can click on it and copy the large string of characters and numbers.



API keys are coveted (especially for LLM’s). To keep yours safe, store it in the .env file in the main directory. You should have created this file along with the folders in the last step. This environment variable file store important and sensitive data for you. The code for this file looks like the following:

GEMINI_API_KEY = 12345 # replace this with your key

Lastly, save the .env file.
You can now run the below code to install needed packages and load the environment variables from .env into this file




Please run the following in your terminal in VS Code. If you cannot find the terminal there is a tab on the top of the screen called terminal, select New Terminal and paste the code below into it and press ENTER
pip install -q -U langchain langchain-google-genai python-dotenv



This code we need to run inside a notebook. Go into the notebooks folder and create a file called setup.ipynb then create a code chunk and paste in the following code


True


You will need to rerun load_dotenv() every time you open the file again, but not pip install above, which is a one time run



Now that everything is set up, lets see if the LLM will respond to us

from langchain.chat_models import init_chat_model

model = init_chat_model(
    model="gemini-2.5-flash", 
    model_provider="google_genai"
)

model.invoke("Hello world!")

AIMessage(content='Hello there! Welcome! How can I help you today?', additional_kwargs={}, response_metadata={'finish_reason': 'STOP', 'model_name': 'gemini-2.5-flash', 'safety_ratings': [], 'model_provider': 'google_genai'}, id='lc_run--019c0246-d689-7ac1-9a3c-cf91716ba174-0', tool_calls=[], invalid_tool_calls=[], usage_metadata={'input_tokens': 4, 'output_tokens': 42, 'total_tokens': 46, 'input_token_details': {'cache_read': 0}, 'output_token_details': {'reasoning': 30}})


If you got things working, rejoice!
Make sure to help your neighbor gets there too. Then you can continue.
